papers.abstract: Handwritten character recognition is a challenging pattern recognition problem due to the inconsistency of the handwritten scripts and the lack of accurate labeled data. Historical documents written in cursive are even more challenging as characters have unique and varying shapes. Frequently, words are linked by lines and ornamental doodles. When historical documents are digitized, the images contain various types of noise and degradation, which further complicates the recognition of characters. In this paper, we present an empirical study of how well state-of-the-art convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for image classification perform for the task of recognizing handwritten characters in seventeenth-century Spanish American notarial scripts. Professional historians, paleography experts, and trained labelers were involved in preparing the labeled dataset of Spanish characters for training the CNNs. The labeled dataset used in this experiment was created from the manuscripts written by one of the multiple scribes that contributed to the collection of approximately 220,000 digitized images of notary records housed at the Archivo General de la Nación Argentina (National Archives). We removed the noise in these images by applying standard image processing techniques. After training different CNNs, we computed the classification accuracy for all the characters. We observed that ResNet-50 achieved a promising accuracy of 97.08% compared to InceptionResnet-V2, Inception-V3, and VGG-16, which achieved 96.66%, 96.33%, and 70.91%, respectively.

Agent: Handwritten character recognition is a challenging pattern recognition problem

Primary Object: inconsistent handwritten scripts and inaccurate labeled data

Context: Historical documents written in cursive are even more challenging because characters have unique and varying shapes.
Results: When historical documents are digitized, the images contain various types of noise and degradation, which further complicates the recognition of characters.

events.Text: In this paper, we present an empirical study of how well state-of-the-art convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for image classification perform for the task of recognizing handwritten characters in seventeenth-century Spanish American notarial scripts. The labeled dataset used in this experiment was created from the manuscripts written by one of the multiple scribes that contributed to the collection of approximately 220,000 digitized images of notary records housed at the Archivo General de la Nación Argentina (National Archives). We removed the noise in these images by applying standard image processing techniques.

Primary Object: how well state-of-the-art convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for image classification perform for the task of recognizing handwritten characters in seventeenth-century Spanish American notarial scripts

Context: Professional histograms, paleography experts, and trained labelers were involved in preparing the labeled dataset of Spanish characters for training the CNNs.
Method: The labeled dataset used in this experiment was created from the manuscripts written by one of the multiple scribes that contributed to the collection of approximately 220,000 digitized images of notary records housed at the Archivo General de la Nación Argentina (National Archives).
Results: We removed the noise in these images by applying standard image processing techniques.

events.Text: After training different CNNs, we computed the classification accuracy for all the characters. We observed that ResNet-50 achieved a promising accuracy of 97.08% compared to InceptionResnet-V2, Inception-V3, and VGG-16, which achieved 96.66%, 96.33%, and 70.91%, respectively.

papers.abstract: Drawing from the largest and first fully-searchable digital archive of non-fiction essays by incarcerated people writing about their experience inside US prisons and jails, the article proposes that there exists a broad, well-established, but underappreciated mid-range manner of reading that stands between traditional close reading and computer-aided distant reading of first-person witness testimony. This mid-range or “cellular” reading method attends both to the singularity of each text and ventures widely enough to grasp that each text gains credence and expository authority as one among aggregates of witness testimony. It is, moreover, in facilitating such mid-range reading that DH can provide readers with the foundation for moving from secondary witness and into acting for social change.

events.Text: Drawing from the largest and first fully-searchable digital archive of non-fiction essays by incarcerated people writing about their experience inside US prisons and jails, the article proposes that there exists a broad, well-established, but underappreciated mid-range manner of reading that stands between traditional close reading and computer-aided distant reading of first-person witness testimony.

Primary Object: a method involving three distinct phases: initial phase focusing on identifying patterns within individual cells; middle phase involving collaborative analysis among participants; final phase concentrating on interpreting collective patterns across all cells.

events.Text: This mid-range or “cellular” reading method attends both to the singularity of each text and ventures widely enough to grasp that each text gains credence and expository authority as one among aggregates of witness testimony. It is, moreover, in facilitating such mid-range reading that DH can provide readers with the foundation for moving from secondary witness and into acting for social change.
events.Main Action: attend both to the singularity of each text and ventures widely enough to grasp that each text gains credence and expository authority as one among aggregates of witness testimony.

Primary Object: examiner(s)/reader(s) attaining understanding through contextual engagement with texts

Context: it facilitates such mid-range reading where DH contributes to building reader capability for social change
Purpose: to enable readers to transition from secondary witnesses to active participation in societal change
Method: digital humanistics methodologies facilitate this process through interdisciplinary analysis
Results: DH enables readers to gain deeper insights and influence cultural shifts effectively
Analysis: mid-range reading bridges individual comprehension with collective impact across diverse textual sources
Challenge: balance between singular focus and broad applicability remains crucial
Ethical: ethical considerations arise regarding access and representation of primary materials
Implications: this integration opens new avenues for meaningful public discourse enhancement
Contradictions: existing reliance solely on traditional narrative structures may limit alternative perspectives consideration
